And I was making fun
of Maple Leafs fans

4464.text:
at a presentation I was
doing just outside Toronto.

4468.text:
Because the way the
place was set up,

4473.text:
it was just all chairs
sitting on the floor.

4475.text:
So the people in
back couldn't see me,

4477.text:
And I told them, I'm not
the tallest presenter

4480.text:
I might not even be the best
presenter you've ever had.

4482.text:
But in a room full
of Leafs fans,

4483.text: you're used to being let down.

4485.text:
And then two days later,
the Leafs played the flames

4487.text:
and the Leafs won, so
I was eating my words.

4490.text:
I don't make those
jokes anymore.

4492.text:
MALE SPEAKER: And then
there are a couple

4495.text:
One is, what, if any, Google
products-- YouTube, Gmail,

4498.text:
Google Maps, do you
use, and can you

4500.text:
tell us about your
experience using them?

4503.text:
CHRIS KOCH: I use Google
Maps all the time.

4509.text:
I was going to, at the very
beginning of my presentation,

4512.text:
say, sorry, I just have to
check my Hotmail really quickly.

4514.text: But I forgot to do that.

4516.text:
So yeah, I use a lot
of the Google-- Maps,

4525.text:
That has come in very, very
handy on numerous occasions.

4530.text:
I would say, other
than Maps, Translate.

4541.text:
Chris, what are some of
the toughest obstacles you

4543.text: face in your day to day life?

4544.text:
Can technology help to
alleviate some of them?

4547.text:
CHRIS KOCH: Such
simple, little things.

4550.text:
Ironing my shirt-- I once
bit my lip ironing my shirt.

4555.text:
So obviously, I
was doing it wrong.

4560.text:
When I stay in hotels,
especially if I'm there

4563.text: on my own, I don't know why.

4565.text:
I think it's because when
the cleaners are in before

4570.text:
and they're washing
out the shower,

4572.text:
they turn the shower head
off, put it off to the side

4574.text:
so the shower's not
going right on them

4576.text:
and then they forget
to tip it back.

4579.text:
So when I get in and
that shower head's

4581.text:
pointed against the
wall-- so I have

4584.text:
to shower underneath the
faucet or something like that.

4587.text:
So, just tiny little
things-- and I mean,

4589.text:
I've used broom handles
and my skateboard,

4592.text:
stood up on the side of
the tub held my skateboard

4595.text:
and tipped the shower head
to-- where there's a will,

4599.text:
I've used an ironing board
to move the shower head.

4601.text:
But it's way easier
to just ask Ally, hey,

4604.text:
do you mind moving
the shower head?

4606.text:
When I was traveling
with Anna in Asia,

4610.text:
I couldn't even
turn the shower on,

4612.text:
because all the taps
were up so high.

4614.text:
So I would hide
in behind the door

4616.text:
and she would come in
with her eyes closed

4619.text:
and turn the shower on
and then run back out

4622.text:
and hopefully not hit the
wall and find the doorway

4626.text:
And then when I was done,
[INAUDIBLE] she'd do that.

4628.text:
So yeah, good friends
also help out.

4631.text:
MALE SPEAKER: So, thank you
so much, Chris, for coming.
